user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_:
```c
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *hdr;

  mhd_assert (0 != header_len);
  mhd_assert (0 != content_len);
  if (NULL == (hdr = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header))))
    return false;

  hdr->header = header;
  hdr->header_size = header_len;
  hdr->value = content;
  hdr->value_size = content_len;
  hdr->kind = kind;
  _MHD_insert_header_last (response, hdr);

  return true; /* Success exit point */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_:
#define MHD_calloc_(n, s) calloc((n),(s))
...
#define _MHD_insert_header_last(presponse, phdr) do{mhd_assert(NULL==phdr->next);mhd_assert(NULL==phdr->prev);if(NULL==presponse->last_header){mhd_assert(NULL==presponse->first_header);presponse->last_header=phdr;presponse->first_header=phdr;}else{mhd_assert(NULL!=presponse->first_header);presponse->last_header->next=phdr;phdr->prev=presponse->last_header;presponse->last_header=phdr;}\
}while(0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
explanation: No calls to <string.h> functions appear in the shown function or in the provided macros, so there are no direct uses of memcpy/strcpy/etc. to inspect here. The only operations that could later lead to out-of-bounds accesses by string functions are the acceptance and storage of the caller-supplied pointers and their lengths (the fragments listed above). Other fragments in the code (the calloc macro, the allocation of hdr, and the _MHD_insert_header_last macro) do not themselves invoke or perform buffer accesses via the standard string handling functions and therefore do not need investigation under MISRA C Rule 21.17 in the context of this function.
